prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the "AITA" (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife who also works from home and handles most of the household chores and kids.

First, I need to break down the key points. The husband chose the bedroom over the basement because of the view. His job is mostly conference calls, so the wife has to keep the kids from disturbing him, which restricts her movement in the house. She can't even do basic tasks like showering or doing chores when he's on calls. She suggested the basement, which has more space, but he refused. Now she's saying he's the asshole, but he's countering that she's not keeping him undisturbed. The question is whether she's in the wrong here.

So, the main issue is about shared space and responsibilities. The husband's choice to work in the bedroom is causing her significant inconvenience. She's handling the majority of the housework and childcare, which is already a lot. By choosing the bedroom, he's limiting her ability to function in her own home. The basement was an available alternative that would have minimized disruptions. 

From a fairness perspective, when you have a shared living space, both parties should consider each other's needs. The husband's job allows flexibility (working from home some days), so his choice of workspace affects the household. The wife is managing her work and the household, which is a lot. The fact that she's working from home too adds to the pressure. 

The key point here is that the husband's preference (better view) is causing a major disruption to her daily life. While it's common for people to want to work in comfortable or scenic areas, it shouldn't infringe on another person's ability to live their life in the same house. The basement option was available, which could have been a compromise. By not choosing that, he's prioritizing his comfort over her practical needs.

Additionally, the wife is trying to set boundaries by explaining that she can't guarantee silence in the bedroom but can in the basement. The husband dismissing her concerns and calling her the asshole suggests he's not considering her perspective adequately. 

In relationships, mutual respect and compromise are important. The husband's refusal to consider a more neutral space that reduces conflict seems like a lack of compromise. The wife isn't wrong for wanting to maintain her ability to work and manage the household. She's not obligated to make her own life difficult to accommodate his preferences, especially when a better alternative exists.

So, putting it all together, the author (the wife) is not in the wrong. The husband's choice is causing unnecessary hardship, and the wife is justified in expressing her concerns and pushing for a more reasonable arrangement. Therefore, the answer should be B, meaning the author is not in the wrong.
